questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a red, painful left eye and blurred vision for the past 3 days. She has a history of recurrent anterior uveitis associated with HLA-B27 positivity. On examination, she has ciliary injection, cells, and flare in the anterior chamber, posterior synechiae, and an intraocular pressure of 32 mmHg in the affected eye. Which of the following medications is not appropriate in the medical management of this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pilocarpine is a cholinergic agonist (miotic) that constricts the pupil and increases trabecular outflow. However, in active anterior uveitis, this drug is contraindicated for several reasons:

  • Increases inflammation and pain by contracting the ciliary body.
  • Enhances the formation of posterior synechiae by keeping the pupil constricted and the iris in contact with the lens.
  • Prevents full pupillary dilation required to break existing synechiae.
  • It can contribute to pupillary block and lead to angle-closure glaucoma in the setting of posterior synechiae.

Thus, pilocarpine worsens the underlying condition and increases the risk of complications.

Explanation of other options:

Beta blocker (Option A): (e.g., Timolol) Beta blockers reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous humor production from the ciliary body. They are effective and safe to use in uveitic glaucoma as they do not aggravate inflammation or interfere with the inflammatory process.

Cholinergic antagonist (Option C): (Cycloplegic agent, e.g., Homatropine, Atropine)

Cycloplegics dilate the pupil and paralyze the ciliary muscle, which helps relieve pain from ciliary spasm. They also prevent or break posterior synechiae and reduce the risk of pupillary block, making them essential in the management of active uveitis.

Topical corticosteroid (Option D): (e.g., Prednisolone acetate) Topical corticosteroids are the cornerstone of treatment for active uveitis. They work by suppressing intraocular inflammation and help control the inflammatory rise in intraocular pressure, improving both comfort and visual outcomes.

choices.text: The presence of a small cornea

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with chronic angle-closure glaucoma with relative pupillary block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Peripheral radial iris transillumination defects are seen in pigment dispersion syndrome and pigmentary glaucoma, not in chronic angle-closure glaucoma.
  • They result from the rubbing of the posterior iris against the lens zonules, leading to radial mid-peripheral iris atrophy.
  • In contrast, chronic angle-closure glaucoma typically features a shallow anterior chamber, convex iris, and no iris transillumination defects.

Explanation of other options:

Hyperopia (Option A): Hyperopic (farsighted) eyes are shorter in axial length and tend to have shallow anterior chambers. This makes them anatomically predisposed to pupillary block, increasing the risk of angle closure.

Cataract progression (Option B): A thickened or swollen lens (as seen with aging or cataract formation) pushes the iris forward, further narrowing the anterior chamber angle. This contributes to angle closure and worsening of intraocular pressure in chronic angle-closure glaucoma.

The presence of a small cornea (Option C): Small corneal diameter is often associated with nanophthalmos or short axial length, leading to crowded anterior segment anatomy. Such anatomical configurations increase the risk of relative pupillary block and chronic angle closure.

choices.text: Inability to adequately view the trabecular meshwork in an eye with a narrow angle
Chronic primary angle closure glaucoma prior to performing laser trabeculoplasty

questions.text: Laser iridotomy is not indicated in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neovascular glaucoma involves fibrovascular membrane formation over the angle and iris, pulling the iris forward and causing secondary angle closure.
  • This is not due to pupillary block, but rather anterior synechial closure from neovascularization.
  • Therefore, laser iridotomy is ineffective, as it does not relieve the underlying cause.

Neovascular Glaucoma (NVG):

A secondary glaucoma resulting from neovascularization of the anterior segment (iris and angle), usually secondary to retinal ischemia.

Key Features

  • Neovascularization of the iris, angle, and anterior chamber
  • Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP)
  • Peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS)

Associated Features

  • Decreased vision
  • Ectropion uveae
  • Anterior chamber inflammation
  • Optic nerve cupping
  • Corneal edema (depending on acuteness)
  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Underlying retinal ischemic, inflammatory, or neoplastic disease

Pathogenesis

  • Triggered by retinal ischemia, leading to VEGF secretion
  • VEGF causes new vessel growth over the iris and angle → formation of fibrovascular membrane
  • This membrane contracts → angle closure by PAS → raised IOP
  • Inflammation and angiopoietins (1 & 2) also contribute

Diagnosis

  • Based on clinical examination: slit-lamp + gonioscopy (undilated pupil)
  • New vessels may start at the pupillary margin before angle involvement
  • FA of the iris or retina helps when vessels are not clinically visible
  • Electroretinogram b: a wave ratio <1.0 in eyes that develop NVG post-CRVO

Treatment

  • Preventive/Early Stage
    • Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP): first-line therapy to eliminate ischemic drive
    • Anti-VEGF (e.g., bevacizumab): reduces anterior neovascularization and IOP temporarily
    • Steroids (e.g., triamcinolone): reduce inflammation and neovascular drive
  • With Angle Closure or High IOP
    • Medical therapy: beta-blockers, alpha-agonists, CAIs(Miotics are avoided - worsen inflammation)
    • Surgery (if vision is potentially salvageable):
      • Trabeculectomy (preferably after PRP)
      • Glaucoma drainage implants (e.g., Baerveldt, Molteno)
      • Cyclophotocoagulation if advanced or vision-poor eyes
  • For Painful Blind Eyes
    • Cycloablation
    • Retrobulbar alcohol injection
    • Enucleation

Explanation of other options:

Inability to adequately view the trabecular meshwork in an eye with a narrow angle (Option A): In such cases, the angle may be narrow due to relative pupillary block. Laser iridotomy can open the angle by relieving the block, restoring visibility, and allowing further interventions like laser trabeculoplasty.

Pseudophakic pupillary block glaucoma (Option B): Although the natural lens is removed, blockage can still occur due to posterior chamber anomalies. Laser iridotomy is indicated to create an alternate pathway for aqueous flow and relieve the blockage.

Chronic primary angle-closure glaucoma before performing laser trabeculoplasty (Option C): If the angle is too narrow for laser trabeculoplasty but not fully synechially closed, laser iridotomy is performed first. This opens the angle enough to safely perform trabeculoplasty later.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man experienced unilateral sudden loss of vision 1 year previously. Currently, he complains of severe pain in that eye. Examination reveals no light-perception vision, intraocular pressure of 72 mm Hg, iris neovascularization, and evidence of a central retinal vein occlusion. What would the least helpful topical therapeutic agent be at this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a classic presentation of end-stage neovascular glaucoma (NVG), secondary to retinal ischemia from CRVO.
  • The presence of iris neovascularization (rubeosis iridis), very high IOP, and a history of sudden vision loss from CRVO support this diagnosis.
  • In NVG, ischemic retinal tissue releases VEGF, causing new vessels to form on the iris and angle. These vessels form a fibrovascular membrane that contracts and closes the anterior chamber angle, causing a secondary angle-closure glaucoma. Over time, this leads to irreversible damage and blindness, as seen in this patient.

This eye has no visual potential (no light perception) and extremely high IOP, causing pain.

At this stage, treatment is palliative-aimed at relieving pain and inflammation, not restoring vision or aggressively lowering IOP.

  • Cholinergic agents (e.g., pilocarpine) work by contracting the ciliary muscle, increasing trabecular outflow.
  • But in NVG, the angle is already closed by fibrovascular tissue and synechiae, so this outflow route is blocked.
  • Worse, miotics cause ciliary spasm, which increases pain and enhances inflammation, making the eye more uncomfortable.
  • Thus, cholinergic agents are ineffective and counterproductive in this setting.

Explanation of other options:

Beta blocker (Option A): Reduces aqueous production. Although it may not lower IOP significantly in a fully closed angle, it is non-irritating and may offer slight pressure relief and comfort.

Corticosteroid (Option B): Reduces inflammation in the anterior chamber. Helps relieve ocular discomfort and is appropriate in palliative care for a painful blind eye.

Cycloplegic (Option D): Relieves ciliary muscle spasm, which is a major cause of deep ocular pain. Also stabilizes the blood-aqueous barrier and reduces inflammation. Very helpful for comfort and pain control in blind, inflamed eyes.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an example of a valved aqueous shunt (glaucoma drainage implant)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ahmed implant is a valved glaucoma drainage device, designed to prevent postoperative hypotony (IOP too low) by restricting outflow until IOP exceeds a certain threshold (typically 8-10 mmHg).
  • It features a venturi-type valve that opens only when pressure is high enough, thus regulating flow from the anterior chamber to the subconjunctival space.

Explanation of other options:

Schocket Implant (Option A):

  • One of the earlier types of non-valved glaucoma drainage implants.
  • Allows free flow of aqueous humor, which risks early postoperative hypotony.
  • Requires temporary flow restriction (e.g., external ligature or stenting) until the plate is encapsulated.

Molteno Implant (Option B):

  • The first glaucoma drainage device developed.
  • Consists of a tube and a single or double plate.
  • No internal valve, so aqueous flows freely unless restricted externally.
  • Temporary ligature or occlusion is used initially to prevent hypotony.
  • Still in use, especially in certain refractory glaucomas.

Baerveldt Implant (Option C):

  • A large surface area device designed for greater long-term IOP reduction.
  • No valve mechanism, so it requires initial occlusion of the tube (e.g., using a dissolvable suture).
  • Once the plate becomes encapsulated by fibrous tissue, flow stabilizes.
  • Popular in cases requiring long-term pressure control (e.g., NVG, uveitic glaucoma).

choices.text: Amount of glaucomatous optic nerve damage at presentation
Level of intraocular pressure at presentation

questions.text: Which of the following is the most helpful clue in the diagnosis of chronic primary angle-closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patients with chronic primary angle-closure glaucoma can present with intraocular pressure that is low, normal, or elevated. Ocular symptoms may or may not be present. There may be any degree of glaucomatous optic nerve damage or no damage at all. Gonioscopic findings, preferably with the Zeiss or Posner lens, are the key to the diagnosis of chronic primary angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for developing primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Short axial length is a key anatomical risk factor for developing Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma (PACG) because it contributes to a shallow anterior chamber and a crowded anterior segment, which increases the risk of pupillary block and angle closure.
  • This anatomical configuration narrows the iridocorneal angle, making aqueous outflow more difficult and predisposing the eye to sudden or chronic rises in intraocular pressure.

PACG occurs most often in individuals with specific structural predispositions. These include:

  • Short axial length
  • Shallow anterior chamber depth (particularly peripherally)
  • Thick or anteriorly positioned lens
  • Small corneal diameter and steeper corneal curvature

Advanced imaging techniques like anterior segment OCT (AS-OCT) have helped identify further anatomical risks, such as:

  • Smaller trabecular-iris space area
  • Increased lens vault
  • Greater iris thickness
  • Flatter iris curvature

In addition to anatomical factors, several demographic features increase PACG risk:

  • Age >60 years
  • Female sex (2-4× higher prevalence than in men)
  • Chinese and East Asian ethnicities
  • Positive family history, especially in first-degree relatives, due to heritable ocular anatomy

Precipitating factors can trigger acute angle closure in predisposed eyes. These include:

  • Dim lighting (physiological pupillary dilation narrows the angle)
  • Certain medications, especially:
    • Anticholinergics (e.g., atropine, antihistamines, tricyclic antidepressants)
    • Adrenergic agents (e.g., phenylephrine, systemic vasoconstrictors and bronchodilators)

Examination of other options:

Myopia (Option A): Myopic eyes have a long axial length and a deep anterior chamber. This anatomical configuration reduces the risk of pupillary block and angle closure. PACG is more commonly associated with hyperopia, not myopia.

Male gender (Option B): PACG is 2-4 times more common in females. Women typically have shorter axial lengths and shallower anterior chambers, predisposing them to angle closure. Therefore, male gender is not a risk factor-in fact, it is relatively protective.

Young age (Option D): The risk of PACG increases with age, especially after 60 years. Aging causes the lens to thicken and move forward, further narrowing the anterior chamber angle. Young age is not a risk factor; it is the elderly population that is more susceptible.

choices.text: C = SL A = Ant. TM B = Post. TM D = CBB
A = SL B = Ant. TM C = Post. TM D = CBB
A = CBB B = Ant. TM C = Post. TM D = SL
A = SL C = Ant. TM D = Post. TM B = CBB

questions.text: Identify structures A, B, C, and D:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a gonioscopic view of the anterior chamber angle structures, as seen during gonioscopy, a technique used to visualize the iridocorneal angle.

In gonioscopy, the structures are viewed from anterior (cornea) to posterior (iris root). The correct anatomical order of the labeled structures is:

  • A = Schwalbe's Line (SL):
    • The most anterior angle landmark
    • Marks the termination of Descemet's membrane
    • Appears as a thin, glistening line
  • B = Anterior Trabecular Meshwork (Ant. TM):
    • Non-pigmented and not involved in aqueous outflow
    • Lies just posterior to Schwalbe's line
  • C = Posterior Trabecular Meshwork (Post. TM):
    • Pigmented and functional part of TM
    • Responsible for aqueous humor drainage
  • D = Ciliary Body Band (CBB):
    • The most posterior structure
    • Gray to brown band seen between the scleral spur and the iris root
    • Prominent in myopic or post-iridotomy eyes

questions.text: Sickle sickle-shaped extension of the blind spot is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

It occurs when the blind spot extends to the paracentral scotoma

questions.text: False about normal tension glaucoma is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rather, in NTG also visual defects are seen.

questions.text: Tubular vision is seen in
Which of the following is not a provocative test for angle closure glaucoma
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The water drinking test involves rapid ingestion of a large volume of water to assess the eye's ability to handle sudden fluid shifts and was historically used to evaluate aqueous outflow, particularly in open-angle glaucoma.
  • It is not used as a provocative test for angle-closure glaucoma because it does not mimic mechanisms like pupillary block or angle crowding, and is now considered obsolete in most clinical settings.

Explanation of other options:

Prone Position Test (Option B): Involves the patient lying face down (prone) for a set duration. This position causes forward movement of the lens-iris diaphragm, narrowing the angle and potentially provoking angle closure. It mimics real-life situations like reading or sleeping prone in susceptible eyes.

Mydriatic Test (Option C): Uses pharmacologic agents (e.g., tropicamide, phenylephrine) to dilate the pupil. Mydriasis causes the peripheral iris to bunch up, narrowing the anterior chamber angle and potentially triggering an angle-closure attack in predisposed individuals.

Dark Room Test (Option D): The patient is placed in complete darkness for 30-60 minutes, allowing physiologic mydriasis to occur. Like the mydriatic test, this increases iris-lens apposition and may cause pupillary block, which can precipitate angle closure. Useful in diagnosing latent angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: Vogt's triad includes all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Posterior subcapsular cataract is not part of Vogt's triad.
  • It is associated with chronic steroid use, radiation, or aging, and is seen in various conditions, including chronic uveitis and prolonged glaucoma, but is not specifically a marker of past acute angle-closure.

Vogt's triad refers to classic clinical signs indicating a previous acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG) attack. It was described by Alfred Vogt and includes the following:

Components of Vogt's Triad (Mnemonic: PIG)

  • P - Pupil fixed and dilated (Option D ruled out)
    • Due to ischemia of the iris sphincter caused by acutely elevated IOP
  • I - Iris atrophy (Option C ruled out)
    • Sectoral atrophy of the iris results from ischemic damage
  • G - Glaukomflecken (Option A ruled out)
    • Small anterior subcapsular opacities on the lens due to ischemic necrosis of the lens epithelium

questions.text: Prophylactic treatment for the fellow eye in ACG is

choices.text: The eclipse sign may be seen
The visual field is usually normal

questions.text: False about angle closure glaucoma attack
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Disc shows cupping is false because in an acute angle-closure glaucoma attack, the optic disc typically appears normal or hyperemic, not cupped.
  • Cupping develops over time with chronic pressure damage, as seen in primary open-angle glaucoma, not during the acute phase.

Explanation of other options:

The eclipse sign may be seen (Option A): Also known as the shadow test. A crescent shadow on the nasal side of the iris is seen when light is shone from the temporal side. Indicates a shallow anterior chamber, which is common in eyes predisposed to angle closure.

Rock hard eyeball (Option B): True in acute angle-closure glaucoma. The IOP rises acutely (often >40-60 mmHg), making the globe firm to palpation (rock hard).

The visual field is usually normal (Option D): In acute attacks, the visual field is initially unaffected. Field defects develop only after sustained or repeated pressure elevations, causing optic nerve damage.

questions.text: Symptoms of POAG are

A male patient with a history of hypermature cataract presents with a 2-day history of ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision, and on examination has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has a hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract with a deep anterior chamber and signs of inflammation (ciliary congestion, photophobia) and blurred vision.
  • The key to the diagnosis is the deep anterior chamber, which rules out angle-closure mechanisms like phacomorphic glaucoma.
  • In phacolytic glaucoma, high-molecular-weight lens proteins leak through an intact capsule, attracting macrophages that clog the trabecular meshwork, leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma.
  • The intraocular pressure rises, but the angle remains open, consistent with a deep anterior chamber.

Explanation of other options:

Phacomorphic Glaucoma (Option A): This is a secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by a swollen (intumescent) lens in a mature cataract. It presents with a shallow anterior chamber and signs of pupillary block, which were not seen in this case. Hence, ruled out.

Phacotoxic Glaucoma (Option C): An outdated term for lens-particle glaucoma, it refers to trabecular inflammation following exposure to retained lens fragments, usually post-trauma or surgery. This patient's lens is intact and hypermature, not post-surgical, making this unlikely.

Phacoanaphylactic Uveitis (Phacoantigenic Uveitis) (Option D): A granulomatous immune reaction to lens proteins after lens capsule rupture (surgical or traumatic). It presents with severe inflammation, often bilateral, and requires prior capsular breach, which is not present here. The lens in phacolytic glaucoma is intact.

questions.text: A 48 year old man has complaints of frequent change of presbyopic glasses. On examination his vision is 6/6, angles are open with an IOP of 20 mmHg on goldmann applanation tonometer. His mother had open angle glaucoma. His CCT is 450 microns. Retina checkup reveals a CDR of 0.7 : 1. His visual fields are normal. What is next step you will plan.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient likely has primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) or is at very high risk of progression, even though the visual field is still normal.

  • CDR of 0.7 is concerning for early optic nerve damage.
  • Thin central corneal thickness (CCT = 450 microns) leads to underestimation of IOP. So the true IOP is likely higher than 20 mmHg.
  • A family history of POAG (mother) is a strong risk factor.
  • Frequent changes in presbyopic glasses may indicate fluctuating vision due to subtle progression.
  • Normal fields do not rule out early glaucoma (this may be pre-perimetric glaucoma).

Hence, this is a pre-perimetric or early POAG, and starting antiglaucoma medications is appropriate to prevent further damage.

Explanation of other options:

No intervention required (Option A): Incorrect. With multiple risk factors (CDR, thin cornea, family history), watchful waiting alone is inappropriate.

Repeat test after 1 year (Option C): Inadequate follow-up for a patient with optic nerve changes and underestimated IOP.

Gonioscopy and PI (Option D): PI (peripheral iridotomy) is done for angle-closure or narrow angles. This patient has open angles, so this is not indicated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female who has a refractive error of +2 DS in both eyes suffered from colored haloes for a few days. When she went to see a movie in the theatre, she developed a mild headache and eye pain on the right side. When she came to you for a routine checkup, it was found that her intraocular pressure (IOP) is 24 mmHg in the right eye and 21 mmHg in the left eye. Her gonioscopy shows a narrow angle. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient shows signs of intermittent angle closure in the right eye (colored haloes, eye pain, elevated IOP), and has narrow angles in both eyes. She is hypermetropic, increasing the risk for primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG).

Reasoning for bilateral YAG PI:

  • Laser Peripheral Iridotomy (PI) relieves relative pupillary block, which is the main mechanism in PACG.
  • The fellow eye is at high risk even if asymptomatic.
  • Prophylactic PI in both eyes is recommended to prevent an acute attack.

Explanation of other options:

YAG PI of RE only (Option A): Inadequate - the left eye is at risk and should also be treated.

Wait and watch (Option B): Not advised in symptomatic narrow angles.

Visual fields analysis (Option C): Not the priority now; angle closure must be addressed first.

choices.text: Done by a double-frequency Nd: Yag laser
Treatment of choice for angle closure glaucoma
Done in mid mid-peripheral part of the iris
Useful when adhesions in the angle are less

questions.text: What is incorrect about this procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image described is of a Peripheral Iridotomy (PI), a laser procedure performed to relieve relative pupillary blocking angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Peripheral iridotomy (PI) is not done using a double-frequency Nd: YAG laser (532 nm).
  • PI is performed using:
    • Nd: YAG laser (infrared, 1064 nm) - common in modern practice.
    • Or argon laser (blue-green, 488-514 nm) in older methods, or when tissue pigmentation requires photocoagulation.
  • Double frequency Nd: YAG (532 nm) is used for retinal photocoagulation, not for creating holes in the iris.

Explanation of other options:

Treatment of choice for angle-closure glaucoma(Option B): PI is the first-line treatment for pupillary block-related angle-closure glaucoma. It provides an alternate route for aqueous humor to flow from the posterior to the anterior chamber.

Done in mid-peripheral part of iris (Option C): The iridotomy is ideally created in the mid-peripheral iris, typically in the superotemporal quadrant, to prevent visual disturbances (e.g., glare, ghost images) and ensure functional and cosmetic outcomes.

Useful when adhesions in the angle are less (Option D): PI is most effective before extensive peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) develop. Once significant PAS has formed, iridotomy alone may not relieve angle closure, and additional interventions (e.g., trabeculectomy) might be necessary.
